reviewText: Cute, silly, and violent. This game is a fun introduction to the world of the Rabbids and the hijinks they get up to. Consisting of a variety of minigames, this is the perfect game to try with your friends (locally only), or if you feel like having a good laugh. The story is mildly important, but I really didn't care too much about it with all the crazyness erupting from the Rabbids on a regular basis.

reviewText: People typically hate on this game for inevitably being the decent of Rayman games for half a decade, and that is actually true. Though I do wish this turned out to be the full fledged Rayman 4" that it was supposed to be
date: this game is still fun.\n\nI grew up a huge Rayman fan because of the characters
recommended: they were so entertaining. The Rabbids are an entertaining group
hoursPlayed: as proved by a line of sequels
voteText: mainstream merchandise. and a television show. Since Rabbids are your only source of character selection here
votesHelpful: alas the Rabbids continue to entertain with their outlandish behaviors.\n\nIf you want to play Rayman 4 the way it was initially planned
votesTotal: just buy the DS version. It's literally unchanged from it's initial standpoint. Of course it's not the full Rayman 4 PC experience as it would have been
votesFunny: but it's the original idea of the game as it was intended for the DS (suspicion leads me to believe they were almost finished the DS version and didn't want to re-make it as a mini-game collection so finished it up as Rayman 4 style). It's actually a pretty fun game
commentsCount: too. The sequels on the DS however are understandably just mini-game collections
column17:
for the most part; dull.

So that wraps up my long-ish but comparatively short opinion on Rabbids overflowing the series.
Do I recommend this game? As a standalone title; yes. It's fun and can be revisited from time to time.
Do I recommend this as a Rayman game and to Rayman fans? Not to the full spectrum

reviewText: It is this kind of games that makes you wish that it existed a Neutral" button for the recommendations. But since there isn't
date:
I've got to be more harsh. I will review this under a gamer perspective and with a Rayman fan perspective.

Rayman Raving Rabbids is not very far for accomplishing a decade (already?) since it was released in the market for different platforms including PC. Did it pass through the test of time? I'm affraid not.

To start
recommended: this game carries a sad history of development. Ubisoft originally planned to make a real sequel to Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc (Please bring this game on STEAM
hoursPlayed: guys. Consider also other titles. I am sure many people will be pleased.) for the platforms of the time until one day the development kit of the Wii console arrived to the team's hands. This was the beginning of the end. A very tight deadline for the release of the game along with the console and the discovering of the potential of motion controls were the main reasons why the ambitious "Rayman 4" project saw its canceling. The final result was transforming a main title to a spin-off title. From a platformer to a compilation of party mini-games.\n\nStorywise
voteText: the game is underwhelming: Rayman is captured by a horde of Rabbids and trapped in their colosseum for 15 days and nobody understands why (it was never explained what was their real intention). You entertain them by beating up their challenges and eventually start loving you instead of wanting to shread you in pieces. As a reward for entertainment they offer you plungers. And during your progress
helpfulPercent: Rayman releases that plungers are the key to his freedom. The "story" itself isn't what it is truly underwhelming
votesHelpful: but yes the way the game ends. As a Rayman fan
votesTotal: I was very sad to see such a disappointing ending as I don't really find it worth the effort of beating the game (and dignifying to the main character too). It leaves an ambiguity too but I won't explain it here as it is not the main focus of this review.\n\nGraphicaly
votesFunny: this game does not surprise much even for its time. Obviously
commentsCount: it is one of the versions with best graphical presentation along with the Xbox 360 port. It is probably the only thing I can recommend people to play this version instead of Wii's. The scenarios are really random pretty much as a result of picking up the leftovers of a canceled game
column16: varying since western backgrounds until graveyards. But they don't vary that much so you'll naturally ask often to yourself "Have I seen this before?". Since this was the very first game where the Rabbids appeared
column17: it is normal that their in-game design is very dated. Rabbids in more modern games are much better modeled and much more expressive. Though as a Rayman fan I am very critic towards the chosen design for the Baby Globoxes. It truly makes me wonder what happened in the design process as they look radically different from the Rayman 2 models
column18: not to mention they became much uglier! And I am not just talking about the lack of scale texture.\n\nMusically
column19: the game offers a decent soundtrack but expect some repetitions. Remember this is a party game. As for the sound effects
column20: it is the same opinion but with an extra note: the iconic and fun screams of the Rabbids will quickly become as unpleasant and irritating as drawing a line with a chalk on a blackboard.\n\nFor the gameplay itself
column21: being this transformed game originally developed for the Wii console it makes sense that the gameplay works fine there. After testing the PC version
column22: I can guarantee that while some mini-games become much easier to play thanks to the advantages of a keyboard (and mouse for some occasions) for the quickness of response and reduction of physical effort
column23: other mini-games became much more difficult than in Wii. I can give "Bunnies can't fly (Part 1 and 2)" as the biggest example of frustration
column24: especially for Part 2 as I am not being able to pass the 185 meters even with the jet boost by the time I am writting this review. It is also expected that the mini-games are fun to play in the platform originally developed for (and it is if you are really new to the Rayman Raving Rabbids trilogy like I was back in the teenagehood) but does it means that it is for other platforms? I confess that the motion controls is what it makes the game more interesting to play. For normal gaming peripherals like a keyboard+mouse it is not that fun and there is very few variation in the controls. In other words
column25: I think the PC port and its equivalents were totally pointless to make despite of the obvious plan of trying to reach most players as possible. It is not fun. If skeptical
column26: I suggest to try out the Wii version and I am confident you will feel the difference. Being this a party game
column27: the mini-games are also much more fun to play in large groups (3 or 4 players) but I hadn't the chance to test this in the PC version though I calculate that unless the players optate for controllers each player must play by turns in order to use the keyboard+mouse. The game features few fun mini-games that are enjoyable
column28: but others are pretty much boring and strange (Bunnies are Ticklish wins the trophy for this category. Really
column29: what the heck was this?). There is a lot of repetitivism too as some minigames will re-appear but with minor changes to make it "more difficult" to play. After finishing the story mode you can replay the minigames to aim for better scores but these are also dated to a certain point as the online leaderboards of RRR do not exist anymore for around 6 years.\n\nFinally
column30: for the longevity and replay value
column31: the game's story mode is easily cleared in less than one week to not say in few hours. Though
column32: I have my doubts that you will want to bother trying out the score mode as it is impossible for the common of mortals to perfect all the mini-games with 1000 points. The unlockables are all content you can find online after few research to the matter. Once you're done with the story mode
column33: you'll more likely nevermore touch the game.\n\nI really have difficulties to recommend in plain year of 2016 a 2006 game port originally developed for the Wii console. The market is oversatured with casual and party titles (very impulsioned by the Wii phenomenom
column34: and recently with the smartdevices boom) and despite of that problem there is a good thing in it: you have a lot of variety to pick with and I am absolutely sure you can find better multiplayer games to play with your friends than this (regardless the plaftform in question). And if it is a game to play alone
column35: the list of games to pick is equally gigantic. In my gamer perspective
column36: this game already has seen better days and I do think you should look for anything else unless you are really really bored and decide to kill time alone or with your local friends (or that you are a great Rayman/Rabbids fan and really want to try out but I think you are not missing much). In a Rayman fan perspective
column37: I ensure you there are much better titles to play. I would rather recommend you (according to the current offer in STEAM by the time I write this review) to purchase Rayman Legends: the game is fun either alone or with friends and the quality is much superior (and no Rabbids are included!). Though
column38: ideally I would recommend Rayman 2: The Great Escape if it was available for purchase on STEAM. I find very strange the original trilogy not being available for purchase
column39: those are the best games.\n\nTo sum up everything I've written above
column40: I do not recommend this game as there are much better alternatives to choose from Ubisoft's hands. You'll thank me later!"

reviewText:
So I wanted to buy this game because it was one of my first games from when I was a kid. I had already gone through it before but I missed playing it so i bought it again. I thought it would be fun but now that we are at a next level in gaming, I find it boring. It used to be epic 10 years ago, but now its boring. So if you want to buy it because you played it in your childhood, then buy it but wait till it goes on sale, because on full price you can buy better games. But now its 2016, so I think you shouldn't try it, its boring. Honestly, I got dissapointed, I thought it would be more fun.

Rating for 2006: 8/10
Rating for 2016: 4/10

reviewText:
I played this game YEARS ago on the PC when I was younger, and I'm surprised my experience in this game hasn't changed in these years.
This game is bugged, and not optimized for PC.
Some mini-games seem like they haven't been playtested through, as it's too difficult or too unfair at most.
It takes ALOT of patience and ALOT of retries, even when you're doing the exact same thing before.
Even if you do the exact same thing in the same mini-game, you get different outcomes.
Minigames like tilting the screen to move the ball to it's destination or closing the bathroom doors are way too difficult, bugged, and is probably better on the Wii.
It's too boring, and mini-games repeat themselves. You can have fun when you play together with children, but the fun won't last THAT long.
Unless you have ALOT of time on your hands, and you're willing to do the same thing OVER and OVER again just to get a Nice job!" message
date: I would not recommend this game. It's a waste of money
recommended: even if it's $5. It's just not worth the $5."

reviewText: I'm gonna be honest. I didn't like this game at all. The controls are terrible at some Minigames, Most of the Minigames are boring and those that aren't you either get to play all the time till you get bored of them too or you barely get to play them at all and the graphics are pretty bland for a game that came out on the Wii and a year later on the Xbox 360. I played the game to 100% Completion and I'm going to say right away... the ending is not worth it.\n\nI would not recommend this game to anyone. Spend your money on another Rayman Game like Rayman 2 or Rayman Origins.

reviewText:
A broken piece of crap game, made by a game studio that only cares to produce crap and then hide from customers, refusing to fix well known and documented issues.

For example, you cannot finish some games due to glitches. Some common controllers are not supported. You cannot get a refund. Bought this game for my kids, in the day where we have emulators that can accept four inputs on a PC with great hardware, and its free a paid game studio/publisher can't make a single game work correctly.


Vote with your wallet.
